 Installing Cloud Pak for Data on Red Hat OpenShift
(without IBM Cloud Private) 
You can install IBM速 Cloud Pak for Data on OpenShift environment.  
 Before you begin 
 
To install Cloud Pak for Data on OpenShift, ensure that your environment meets the
following requirements:
Software requirements
OpenShift Version 3.11
Helm/Tiller Version 2.9.1 For more information, see Getting started with Helm
on OpenShift on the Red Hat OpenShift blog. 
In addition:
Your cluster must have one and only one Helm/Tiller instance. You can
initialize a Helm/Tiller installation on any host that can access the OpenShift
cluster.
The location of the Helm binary must be set in the PATH environment
variable.
The helm list command must work.
The Tiller service account in the Tiller installation namespace must have the
cluster-admin role:oc adm policy add-cluster-role-to-user cluster-admin system:serviceaccount:
tiller-namespace:tiller 
 Replace tiller-namespace with the namespace where Tiller is installed.

The following minimum recommendations are for the Cloud Pak for Data
installation.

 Testing the load balancer 
It is good practice to test the load balancer that is used with IBM速 Cloud Pak for
Data. 
 Procedure 
 
Verify that you have the ncat utility installed on all master nodes by using the
which ncat command.If the command returns nothing, install the ncat
package on your master nodes with the command: yum install -y nc 
 
On each master node, use ncat to listen for connections on the port that you are
testing by running the following command:ncat -lkp port_number 
The command doesn't return a result because the ncat utility is waiting for an
incoming connection on the specified port_number. 
 
On a different Linux system with a connection to the load balancer system, run
the command:echo 1 | ncat load-balancer-ip-addressport_number 
 
On one of the master nodes, the ncat utility prints a 1 on the screen. 
 
Each time that you run the command, a 1 is randomly printed on one of the
master nodes, as determined by the load balancer.Make sure to test all ports that
are used by Cloud Pak for Data. The required ports are 80, 443, 8001, 8443,
8600, 9443, and 31843. 
When you confirm that all master nodes are able to print 1, stop the ncat
process on the master nodes with the Ctrl+C keyboard combination.
If you do not see the expected results, verify the load balancer configuration, and
make sure that you are not blocked by a firewall or proxy.

 Securing communication ports 
To ensure secure transmission of network traffic to and from the IBM速 Cloud Pak
for Data cluster, you need to configure the communication ports used by the
network. Use the following information to determine which specific ports to configure
for your cloud platform. 
 Existing IBM Cloud Private environments 
If you are installing Cloud Pak for Data on IBM Cloud Private, see the official
documentation on the required ports for IBM Cloud Private. The references in that
document to the Management, Proxy, and Master nodes, all correspond to the
Cloud Pak for Data master node. Also, you do not need to open the ports for
GlusterFS, IBM Multicloud Manager, or IBM Edge Computing for Servers. 
 Installation of Cloud Pak for Data 
When you install Cloud Pak for Data, either as a stand-alone deployment or on top
of an existing cluster, additional ports need to be opened for the nodes to
communicate properly.  
Use the security or network management interface specific to your cloud platform.
For each of the following ports, create a security rule that allows inbound and
outbound connections through the firewall:
22
Port for Secure Shell (SSH) connections. Required during installation for
communications between cluster nodes
31843
Port used by the default instance of Cloud Pak for Data, for connections to the
Cloud Pak for Data web client and for REST API clients
 
After the Cloud Pak for Data installation process is complete, configure your firewall
for maximum security of your connection ports. Allow all outbound traffic from the
cluster, but allow inbound traffic only on the port range that is required for clients to
communicate with the Cloud Pak for Data cluster:
30000-32767
External port range used by the cluster when mapping internal cluster services
to external facing ports.This port range includes port 31843, the port used by
the default instance of Cloud Pak for Data for connections to the web client and
for REST API clients. Each additional instance on the Cloud Pak for Data
cluster has a unique default port for those connections. 
 
 Ports for add-ons 
When you provision a new add-on or integration on your Cloud Pak for Data cluster,
the services might require connections to be made from outside the cluster. For
example, when you access databases, or run data virtualization through an
ODBC/JDBC connection. If the add-on or integration requires connections to be
made to the cluster, then you need to open the appropriate network ports. Refer to
the detailed information for your specific add-on or integration to determine what
extra connections might need to be configured. 
 Securing Transport Layer Security ports 
After you install Cloud Pak for Data, it is  recommended that you complete the steps
for Configuring TLS and cipher suites for the image manager and registry in the
IBM Cloud Private documentation. If you do not complete this task, TLS ports are
79
vulnerable through TLS 1.0/1.1.

 Installing multiple instances of Cloud Pak for Data
on the same IBM Cloud Private cluster 
After you finish installing IBM速 Cloud Pak for Data on a cluster, you can reuse the
same specifications to install another instance of the same Cloud Pak for Data
release on the same cluster. This new instance must use a different namespace and
port number. 
 Before you begin 
 
Requirement: A Cloud Pak for Data Version 2.1.0.2 or later installation in an existing
IBM Cloud Private environment on Red Hat Enterprise Linux using NFS storage
only. Ensure the cluster has enough resource for the new instance. 
 About this task 
 
Cloud Pak for Data supports a multitenancy architecture where different areas of
your organization can share the same cluster, yet operate independently in their
own dedicated Cloud Pak for Data instances. Each instance has its own isolated
users, data, quotas, namespace and ports. 
 Procedure 
 
Create a namespace (cannot exceed eight characters) and docker secret for the
new Cloud Pak for Data instance:kubectl create namespace NEW_NAMESPACE 
kubectl create secret -n NEW_NAMESPACE docker-registry icp4d-anyuid-docker-pull --docker-server=
DOCKER_REGISTRY_URL --docker-username=admin --docker-password=DOCKER_REGISTRY_PASSWORD 
 
Go to the /ibm/InstallPackages/components directory and run ./installer.sh.
Respond to the following installation prompts:
Specify the new namespace you created.
Specify a different console port from your previous installation.The valid port
range is 30000-32767. 
Specify the cluster Docker image prefix, for example
mycluster.icp:8500/zen, and press Enter.This is the address that your
nodes use to access the Docker registry. 
Specify whether the external Docker image prefix is the same as the cluster
Docker image prefix. For example, you might specify a different external
Docker image prefix if you are performing the installation from a host that is
external to your cluster. 
Enter Y to use the cluster Docker image prefix as the external Docker.
Enter N to specify a different external Docker image prefix. You are prompted
to enter the address of your Docker registry. The address can have one of
the following formats:
hostname
hostname:port_number
 
Enter N to select a different storage class from the default.

After the installation of the new instance completes, enter the following command

namespaces|grep ibm-nginx 
Copy the port name for the client URL so that you can sign into the new instance

 What to do next 
 
Recommendation: Set a resource quota on each namespace to ensure the Cloud
Pak for Data instances cannot overuse the CPU, memory, and storage resources on
the cluster. See Setting resource quota for instructions. 
 After you install the new Cloud Pak for Data instance, you must complete the
following tasks:
Complete Setting up the Cloud Pak for Data web client.
IBM Cloud Private restriction: When accessing a Cloud Pak for Data instance,
ensure you sign out before you access a different instance on a different port. Using
the same browser session (for example, in different browser tabs) can result in
authorization failures. Alternatively, you can use a different load balancer host for
each Cloud Pak for Data instance or use a DNS-based route to identify each Cloud
Pak for Data instance (where each instance is identified by a different host name but
can still point to the same proxy or load balancer IP address). Note that this
restriction does not apply to OpenShift because it uses routes. 
Data governance troubleshooting tip: If the data governance feature in the new
Cloud Pak for Data instance stalls on iis-xmetarepro and this pod is not coming
up, then check the nodes on which iis-xmetarepro pods of both instances are
scheduled to see whether they are scheduled on same node. For each namespace
enter the following command:kubectl get po -o wide -n namespace | grep iis-xmetarepro 
If both pods are scheduled on the same node, then complete the following
workaround to schedule the iis-xmetarepro pod on a different node:
Label the different node to schedule the iis-xmetarepro pod on using the
xmeta= instance2 key and value pair:kubectl label node node_IP xmeta= instance2 
Verify that the label is now on the node: kubectl get nodes --show-labels 
Edit the deployment: kubectl get deploy -n namespace | grep iis-xmeta
kubectl edit deploy -n namespacedeployment_name 
In the node affinity section, insert the key and value under
requiredDuringSchedulingIgnoredDuringExecution:. Example:
nodeSelectorTerms:
- matchExpressions:

on the same Red Hat OpenShift cluster 
After you finish installing IBM速 Cloud Pak for Data on a cluster, you can reuse the
same specifications to install another instance of the same Cloud Pak for Data
release on the same Red Hat OpenShift cluster. This new instance must use a
different namespace.  
 Before you begin 
 
Requirement: A Cloud Pak for Data Version 2.1.0.2 or later installation in an existing
OpenShift environment. Ensure the cluster has enough resource for the new
instance, and ensure the cluster has only one Tiller pod. 
 About this task 
 
Cloud Pak for Data supports a multitenancy architecture where different areas of
your organization can share the same cluster, yet operate independently in their
own dedicated Cloud Pak for Data instances. Each instance has its own isolated
users, data, quotas, namespace and ports.

Create another project for Cloud Pak for Data with a new namespace and switch

Replace new_namespace with the new namespace you want to use for the new

Export the TILLER_NAMESPACE environment variable with the Tiller

Log into the Docker registry:docker login Docker-registry-URL -u $(oc whoami) -p $(oc whoami -t) 
Replace Docker-registry-URL with the URL of your Docker registry. 
The following example command checks the docker login for the integrated

docker login docker-registry.default.svc:5000 -u ocadmin -p $(oc whoami -t) 
 
Go to the INSTALL_HOME/InstallPackages/components directory and run

Enter Y to use the cluster Docker image prefix as the external Docker.

 Setting up a remote Hadoop cluster to work with
Cloud Pak for Data 
You can set up a remote Hadoop cluster to allow Cloud Pak for Data  users to
securely access the data that resides on a Hadoop cluster and submit jobs to use
the compute resources on the Hadoop cluster.  
The Hadoop integration software is a separately priced feature. To use the
Hadoop integration software, you must purchase the IBM速 Watson Studio
Premium for IBM Cloud Pak for Data package. For more information, contact your
IBM Sales representative.  
Cloud Pak for Data interacts with a Hadoop cluster through the following four
services:
 
Setting up a Hadoop cluster for Cloud Pak for Data entails installing and configuring
the four services. Additionally, for kerberized clusters, the setup entails configuring a
gateway with JWT-based authentication to securely authenticate requests from
Cloud Pak for Data users. Important: The set up tasks must be performed by a
Hadoop administrator. 
 
 Security and authentication for Hadoop 
The Cloud Pak for Data Hadoop registration service eases the setup of a Hadoop
cluster for Cloud Pak for Data, and gives additional functionality of scheduling jobs
as YARN application. 
The Hadoop Integration service is a secure service installed on the edge node of the
Hadoop cluster. Access to the service is restricted to an explicit list of Cloud Pak for
Data clusters via a secure URL. Every request from Cloud Pak for Data includes the
JWT token of the signed in Cloud Pak for Data user, and is authenticated against
the secure URL. The Hadoop Integration service extracts the username from the
JWT token and propagates the username for all data access and job submission on
the Hadoop cluster.  
Edge node requirements
Hardware requirements:
8 GB memory
2 CPU cores
100 GB disk, mounted and available on /var in the local Linux file system. The
installation creates the following directories: /var/log/dsxhi, /var/log/livy, and
/var/log/livy2 to store the logs and /var/run/dsxhi, /var/run/livy and
/var/run/livy2 to store the process IDs. These locations are not configurable.

 In addition, the edge node must meet the following requirements:
Have Python 2.7 installed.
CDH only: Have Java Development Kit Version 1.8 installed.
Have curl 7.19.7-53 or later to allow secure communication between the
Hadoop registration service and Cloud Pak for Data.
Have a service user that can run the Hadoop registration service. This user
should be a valid Linux user with a home directory created in HDFS.
The service user should have the necessary Hadoop Proxyuser privileges in
HDFS, WebHCAT and Livy services to access data and submit asynchronous
jobs as Cloud Pak for Data users. HDP only: If Hadoop or Ranger KMS is
enabled, the service user should have necessary proxyuser privileges in kms-
site.xml.
For a kerberized cluster: Have the keytab for the service user. This
eliminates the need for every Cloud Pak for Data user to have a valid keytab.
Have an available port for the Hadoop registration service. The port for the
Hadoop registration service should be exposed for access from the Cloud Pak
for Data clusters that need to connect to the HDP cluster.
Have an available port for the Hadoop registration Rest service. This port
need not be exposed for external access.
Depending on the service that needs to be exposed by Hadoop registration,
have an available port for Livy for Spark and Livy for Spark 2. These ports do
not need to be exposed for external access.
When submitting jobs to a Hadoop cluster where Kerberos security is not
enabled, the Yarn user should have write access to the directories accessed
by the job.

registration service

  Setting up Hortonworks Data Platform (HDP) to
work with Cloud Pak for Data 
Cloud Pak for Data provides a Hadoop registration service that eases the setup of
an HDP cluster for Cloud Pak for Data. Using the Hadoop registration service is the
recommended approach, and gives additional functionality of scheduling jobs as
YARN application. 
The Hadoop integration software is a separately priced feature. To use the
Hadoop integration software, you must purchase the IBM速 Watson Studio
Premium for IBM Cloud Pak for Data package. For more information, contact your
IBM Sales representative.  
Setting up an HDP cluster for Cloud Pak for Data entails installing and configuring
the following four services.
 Additionally, for kerberized clusters, the setup entails configuring a gateway with
JWT-based authentication to securely authenticate requests from Cloud Pak for
Data users.  
Important: The following tasks must be performed by a Hadoop administrator. 
Set up a HDP cluster with Hadoop registration
Create an edge node
Install the Hadoop registration service
Manage the Hadoop registration service
Add certificates for SSL enabled services
Manage Cloud Pak for Data for Hadoop registration
Hadoop registration URL for secure access from Cloud Pak for Data
Uninstall the Hadoop registration service
 Supported versions 
HDP Version 2.5.6 and later fixpacks
HDP Version 2.6.2 and later fixpacks
HDP Version 3.0.1 and 3.1
 Platforms supported 
Hadoop registration is supported on all platforms supported by the HDP versions. 
 Set up a HDP cluster with Hadoop registration 
Create an edge node
The Hadoop registration service can be installed on a shared edge node if the
resources listed above are exclusively available for Hadoop registration. See
Edge node requirements for the hardware and software requirements. When
the edge node is successfully created, it should have the following components:
The HDFS Gateway Role and YARN Gateway Role installed.
The Spark client installed if the HDP cluster has a Spark service.
Service Purpose
WebHDFS Browse and preview HDFS data
WebHCAT Browse and preview Hive tables
Livy for Spark Submit jobs to Spark on the
Hadoop cluster.
Livy for Spark2 Submit jobs to Spark2 on the
Hadoop cluster.

The Spark2 client installed if the HDP cluster has a Spark2 service.
For a kerberized cluster, have the spnego keytab copied to
/etc/security/keytabs/spnego.service.keytab.
Install the Hadoop registration service
To install and configure the Hadoop registration service on the edge node, the
Hadoop admin must complete the following tasks:
Download the Hadoop registration RPM  to the edge node.
Run the RPM installer. The rpm is installed in /opt/ibm/dsxhi. If running the
install as the service user, run sudo chown <serviceuser> -R
/opt/ibm/dsxhi.
Create a /opt/ibm/dsxhi/conf/dsxhi_install.conf file using
/opt/ibm/dsxhi/conf/dsxhi_install.conf.template.HDP as a reference. Edit the
values in the conf file. For guidance, see the inline documentation in the
dsxhi_install.conf.template.HDP files.
Optional: If you need to set additional properties to control the location of
Java, use a shared truststore, or pass additional Java options, create a
/opt/ibm/dsxhi/conf/dsxhi_env.sh script to export the environment
variables:export JAVA="/usr/jdk64/jdk1.8.0_112/bin/java"
export JAVA_CACERTS=/etc/pki/java/cacerts
export DSXHI_JAVA_OPTS="-Djavax.net.ssl.trustStore=$JAVA_CACERTS" 
In /opt/ibm/dsxhi/bin, run the ./install.py script to install the Hadoop
registration service. The script prompts for inputs on the following options
(alternatively, you can specify the options as flags): 
Accept the license terms (Hadoop registration uses the same license as
Cloud Pak for Data). You can also accept the license through the
dsxhi_license_acceptance property in dsxhi_install.conf.
If the Ambari URL is specified in dsxhi_install.conf, you will be prompted for
the password for the cluster administrator. The value can also be passed
through the --password flag.
The master secret for the gateway service. The value can also be passed
through the --dsxhi_gateway_masster_password flag.
If the default password for Java cacerts truststore has been changed, the
password can be passed through the --
dsxhi_java_cacerts_password flag.
The installation will run pre-checks to validate the prerequisites. If the
cluster_manager_url is not specified in the dsxhi_install.conf file, then the
pre-checks on the proxyuser settings will not be performed. 
After a successful installation, the necessary components (Hadoop registration
gateway service and Hadoop registration rest service) and optional components
(Livy for Spark and Livy for Spark 2) will be started. The component logs are
stored in /var/log/dsxhi, /var/log/livy, and /var/log/livy2. The component PIDs are
stored in /var/run/dsxhi, /var/run/livy, /var/run/livy2, and
/opt/ibm/dsxhi/gateway/logs/. 
To add cacert to the Hadoop registration rest service, go to the /opt/ibm/dsx/util
directory on the edge node and run the add_cert.sh script with the server
address, for example, bash add_cert.sh https://master-
1.ibm.com:443.

Manage the Hadoop registration service
Periodically, the Hadoop admin must manage the Hadoop registration service.
These tasks include:
Check status of the Hadoop registration service
In /opt/ibm/dsxhi/bin, run ./status.py to check the status of Hadoop
registration gateway, Hadoop registration rest server, Livy for Spark and
Livy for Spark services.
Start the Hadoop registration service
In /opt/ibm/dsxhi/bin, run ./start.py to start the Hadoop registration
gateway, Hadoop registration rest server, Livy for Spark and Livy for Spark
services.
Stop the Hadoop registration service
In /opt/ibm/dsxhi/bin, run ./stop.py to stop the Hadoop registration
gateway, Hadoop registration rest server, Livy for Spark and Livy for Spark
services.
Add certificates for SSL enabled services
If the WebHDFS service is SSL enabled, the certificates of the nodemanagers
and datanodes should to be added to the Hadoop registration gateway trust
store. In /opt/ibm/dsxhi/bin/util, run ./add_cert.sh https://host:port
for each of the nodemanagers and datanodes to add the certificates to Hadoop
registration gateway trust store.Alluxio requirement: To connect to Alluxio using
remote Spark with Livy, go to Ambari > HDFS > Config > Custom Core-site >
Add property in the Ambari web client and fs.alluxio.impl configuration for
the remote Spark. See Running Spark on Alluxio  for details. 
Manage Cloud Pak for Data for Hadoop registration
To maintain control over the access to a Hadoop registration service, a Hadoop
admin needs to maintain a list of known Cloud Pak for Data clusters that can
access the Hadoop registration service. A Cloud Pak for Data cluster will be
known by its URL, which should be passed in when adding to or deleting from
the known list. A Hadoop admin can add (or delete) multiple Cloud Pak for Data
clusters to the known list by passing in a comma separated list of Cloud Pak for
Data cluster. Irrespective of the order in which the arguments for add and
delete are specified, the deletes are applied first and then the adds.
Add a Cloud Pak for Data cluster to the known list
In /opt/ibm/dsxhi/bin, run ./manage_known_dsx.py -add
"url1,url2...urlN". Once a Cloud Pak for Data cluster is added to
the known list, the necessary authentication will be setup and the Cloud
Pak for Data admin can be given a URL to securely connect to the Hadoop
registration service.
Delete a Cloud Pak for Data cluster from the known list
In /opt/ibm/dsxhi/bin, run ./manage_known_dsx.py -delete
"url1,url2...urlN".
Hadoop registration URL for secure access from Cloud Pak for Data
In /opt/ibm/dsxhi/bin, run ./manage_known_dsx.py --list to list a table of
all known Cloud Pak for Data clusters and the associated URL that can be used
to securely connect from a Cloud Pak for Data cluster to a Hadoop registration
service. The Cloud Pak for Data admin can then register the Hadoop cluster.
94
-
-
Uninstall the Hadoop registration service
To uninstall the Hadoop registration service and remove the files from
/opt/ibm/dsxhi, a Hadoop admin can run the ./uninstall.py script in
/opt/ibm/dsxhi/bin. The uninstallation logs are stored in /var/log/dsxhi,
/var/log/livy, and /var/log/livy2.

 Enabling Data Virtualization in Red Hat OpenShift 
You can use Data Virtualization in an OpenShift environment. 
 Before you begin 
 
Install IBM速 Cloud Pak for Data on OpenShift.  About this task 
 
When you install Data Virtualization on OpenShift, you can interact with Data
Virtualization in Cloud Pak for Data, while you use the OpenShift's Kubernetes and
Docker Registry that is already installed by Red Hat OpenShift.To enable Data
Virtualization in Red Hat OpenShift, you must complete the following steps:
Configuring your Data Virtualization worker node.
Installing Data Virtualization on OpenShift.
Provisioning Data Virtualization on OpenShift.
 
 
 Configuring your Data Virtualization worker node 
Data Virtualization requires Security Enhanced Linux (SELinux) to be set to
permissive mode. However, this requirement differs from the Red Hat OpenShift
3.11 prerequisites, which require SELinux to be set to enforcing. This
requirement might also conflict with your organization's security policies for Linux
hosts. 
 About this task 
 
To mitigate your security exposure, it is recommended that you select a specific
node in your Red Hat OpenShift cluster where you want to install Data Virtualization
and set SELinux to permissive only on that node. It is recommended that you do
not deploy any other services on this node. 
Additionally, you must label the node as dv-dedicated=selinux so that Data
Virtualization is deployed on the appropriate node. 
 Procedure 
 
Run the following command to get a list of the nodes in your cluster.kubectl get nodes 
 
Select the worker node where you plan to run Data Virtualization pods.You must
ensure that the selected worker node has sufficient resources to run Data
Virtualization. For more information on system requirements to run Data
Virtualization, see Enabling Data Virtualization. If you need to add worker nodes
to your cluster, see the Red Hat OpenShift product documentation.  
 
Run the following command to add the dv-dedicated=selinux label to the
worker node where you plan to run Data Virtualization.kubectl label nodes <node-name> dv-
dedicated=selinux 
 
For example, if the selected node name is called kubernetes-foo-node-
1.c.a-robinson.internal , run the following commandkubectl label nodes
       kubernetes-foo-node-1.c.a-robinson.internal dv-dedicated=selinux

kubectl get nodes --show-labels 
 
The selected node should have the dv-dedicated label. To see a complete list
of labels for the selected node, run the following command.kubectl describe node
nodename 
 Replace nodename with the name of the selected node. For example, if the
selected node is called kubernetes-foo-node-1.c.a-robinson.internal
:kubectl describe node kubernetes-foo-node-1.c.a-robinson.internal 
 
 
In the node that you selected to install Data Virtualization, set
SELINUX=permissive.
Run the setenforce 0 command to change SELinux to permissive mode.
Run the getenforce to validate that SELinux is set to permissive.~]# setenforce 0
~]# getenforce

 Installing Data Virtualization on OpenShift 
 Before you begin 
 
Ensure to configure the worker node where you plan to install Data Virtualization. 
Procedure 
 
Complete the following steps to install Data Virtualization on your OpenShift
environment: 
Obtain the data virtualization add-on package:
Download the appropriate BIN file from IBM Passport Advantage:
For Enterprise Edition, download ICP4DATA_DV_x86_Vnnnbin.
For Cloud Native Edition, download ICP4DATA_CNE_DV_x86_Vnnn.bin.
 where nnn is the version number of the Data Virtualization add-on. 
 
Change to the directory where the file was downloaded and make the BIN file
executable. For example:chmod +x ICP4DATA_DV_x86_Vnnnbin 
where nnn is the version number of the Data Virtualization add-on. 
 
Run the BIN file:./ICP4DATA_DV_x86_Vnnnbin 
where nnn is the version number of the Data Virtualization add-on. 
This file downloads the following TAR file: dv-ppa.tar 
 
Switch to your Cloud Pak for Data project.oc project namespace 
Replace namespace with the namespace where Cloud Pak for Data is deployed.
The default namespace is zen.

 Giving users access to Data Virtualization 
IBM速 Cloud Pak for Data users that need to use Data Virtualization functions must
be assigned specific Data Virtualization roles based on their job description. 
 About this task 
 
Access to Data Virtualization is administered by Cloud Pak for Data user
management functions. Access within Data Virtualization is managed by the Db2速
database manager.
Authentication
If you authenticate to Data Virtualization directly by using JDBC client
applications, you must specify the Data Virtualization username. The Data
Virtualization username is composed of the Cloud Pak for Data user ID of a
corresponding Cloud Pak for Data username.A Data Virtualization Admin must
explicitly add Cloud Pak for Data users to the Data Virtualization service in
order for these users to authenticate to the service directly. When the Data
Virtualization Admin adds a Cloud Pak for Data user to the Data Virtualization
service, the Data Virtualization username and password are automatically
generated for the user. The Data Virtualization username has the following
format: user{id}, where {id} corresponds to the Cloud Pak for Data user ID. 
Authorization
Cloud Pak for Data users are first authorized at a service-level to access the
Data Virtualization service by using the corresponding Data Virtualization
username. Data Virtualization roles are used for authorization, independently of
group membership. Data Virtualization uses role-based access control for
database-level and object-level authorization. Data Virtualization follows
authorization based on the Db2 Authorities and Privilege model. Various
administrative authorities exist at the Data Virtualization instance level and at
the database level. 
 
There are four user roles defined for Data Virtualization. These roles are specific to
the Data Virtualization environment and are granted to existing Cloud Pak for Data
users. In order for a user to have access to the Data Virtualization service, you must
assign them one of the following Data Virtualization roles:
Data Virtualization Admin
The user who provisions the Data Virtualization add-on is automatically
assigned the Data Virtualization Admin role. After the add-on has been
provisioned, the Data Virtualization Admin can give other users access to the
service.The Data Virtualization Admin is considered to be the manager of the
Data Virtualization instance and assigns appropriate Data Virtualization roles to
Cloud Pak for Data users. 
Data Virtualization Engineer
Configures the data sources, virtualizes data, and manages access to virtual
objects. Users with this role can create a virtual table or view and grant access
to it to users with any Data Virtualization role. By default, every virtual object
that is created in Data Virtualization is private. This means that in order for a
virtual object to be accessed by a user other than its creator, access to the
virtual object must be granted.Data source administrators are expected to
provide access to a Data Virtualization Engineer to virtualize data. Users with
229
-

this role service and fulfill data requests from Data Virtualization users.  
Data Virtualization User
Data Virtualization users can request access to virtualized data or data in
general by initiating a data request. Users with this role can create views of
virtual tables to which they have access. 
Data Virtualization Steward
Data Virtualization Stewards can approve requests to publish virtual tables or
views to the enterprise data catalog. 
 
The following table summarizes the Data Virtualization menu functions that each of
the Data Virtualization user roles is able to access. 
Important: If users submit requests to publish virtual tables or views to the enterprise
data catalog, you must give at least one Cloud Pak for Data user with data steward
role access to the Data Virtualization service as a steward. This user can thus
approve publish requests.

 Managing access to virtual objects 
Data Virtualization administrators can grant user access to virtual objects in Data
Virtualization. 
 About this task 
 
Data Virtualization administrators have access to all virtual objects in Data
Virtualization. Data Virtualization stewards have access to all virtual objects that are
created.  Users assigned to the Data Virtualization Admin and Engineer roles can
grant access to specific virtual objects for other users in Data Virtualization. To use
virtual objects, you can:
Manage access to virtual objects
Revoking access to virtual objects for user roles
Managing visibility of virtual objects
Creating schemas
 
 Procedure 
 
To manage user access to virtual objects, complete the following steps: 
From the Data Virtualization page, go to Menu > My data. You can see a list of
virtual objects that you can access. 
Hover over the virtual object name and click the action menu.
Click Manage access.
To grant access to specific users, click Grant access > To specific users:
Select the check box for the username that you want to grant access to the
virtual object.
Click Add.
To grant access to user roles, click Grant access > To Data Virtualization roles:
Select the check box for the Data Virtualization role that you want to grant
access to the virtual object.
Click Add.
To remove a user's access to virtual objects in Data Virtualization:
Select the check box for the username that you want to remove access to the
virtual object.
Click Remove to remove the user's access to Data Virtualization.
To grant all Data Virtualization users access to a virtual object, disable the
Restrict table access option.
To view a list of permissions that were explicitly granted to, or inherited by the
user.
Click Menu > Manage users.
Hover over the username and click the action menu.
Click Manage access
In the Granted permissions tab, you can see virtual objects to which the user
has been explicitly granted access permissions.
In the Inherited permissions tab, you can see virtual objects that the user can
access via inherited permissions. Permissions can be inherited from user
roles, or from virtual objects that are publicly available to all users.

 Revoking access to virtual objects for user roles 
 About this task 
 
To modify access of a user role to a virtual object, complete the following steps: 
Procedure 
 
Click Menu > Manage users > Roles to see the list of roles in Data Virtualization.
You can click the drop-down arrow of a user role to see a list of users that have
been assigned a Data Virtualization role. 
Hover over the user role, click the action menu, and click View and revoke object
privileges. 
Select the check box for the virtual object to which you want to revoke access.
Click Revoke to remove access of users with this role to the virtual object.
 
 Managing visibility of virtual objects 
You can determine whether Data Virtualization users can view virtual objects that
they cannot access. 
 About this task 
 
By default, Data Virtualization users can see column and table names only of virtual
objects that they can access. For example, if a user is not allowed to perform a
SELECT statement on a table, the table is not be listed when you perform the LIST
TABLES operation. Procedure 
 
To manage visibility of virtual objects: 
Click Menu > Service details.
Go to the Virtual object access control section:
Enable the Restrict visibility of virtual objects list to authorized users option to
prevent users from seeing column and table names of virtual objects that they
cannot access. This option is enabled by default.
Disable the Restrict visibility of virtual objects list to authorized users option to
allow users to see column and table names of virtual objects that they cannot
access.
 
 Creating schemas 
You can use schemas to group virtual objects. A virtual object can belong to only
one schema. Use the CREATE SCHEMA statement to create schemas.  
 About this task 
 
If a schema does not exist in your Data Virtualization add-on, you must create a
schema explicitly. Any user can create a schema with their own authorization name
by using a CREATE SCHEMA statement. For example, user with username
USER1001 can create a private schema named USER1001. To enable other users
or roles to use the schema, USER1001 must grant CREATEIN, ALTERIN, or
DROPIN schema permissions to these users or roles. Additionally, granting these
permissions to PUBLIC enables the schema to be shared by all users. 
Data Virtualization Admins can create schemas based on names other than the
234
-
-
-
-
existing users authorization name. Data Virtualization Admins must grant
appropriate permissions to other users or roles for them to use the schema to create
virtual objects. 
As Data Virtualization Admin, you can grant IMPLICIT_SCHEMA permissions to a
user with the Data Virtualization Engineer role for each project. Data Virtualization
Engineers can then create schemas to be used by other users in their project. When
schemas are created by using the IMPLICIT_SCHEMA permission, note that
PUBLIC is granted the CREATIN permission on these schemas. 
 Procedure 
 
To create a schema while creating a virtualized table:
If you have the Data Virtualization Engineer or User roles, leave the Schemas
field as default to create a schema with your user ID.
If you have the Data Virtualization Admin role, enter the new schema name in the
Schemas field.
For more information on how to create virtualized tables, see Virtualizing data. 
To create a schema from the command line or SQL Editor, enter the following
statement: CREATE SCHEMA schema-name 
For more information about creating schemas, see Creating schemas in the Db2速
product documentation.

 Creating an integrated database 
You can optionally create one or more databases within IBM速 Cloud Pak for Data.
After you create an integrated database, you can create a connection to the
database so that the contents of the database can be discovered, governed, and
used for analytics. 
 Integrated databases can be used to:
Offload some of your data workload to the system where the governance and
analysis occurs
Quickly provision databases if you don't have existing databases
Create a sandbox environment
 
You can create several different types of integrated databases in Cloud Pak for Data
. 
Important: The required resources for each database are the minimum
requirements. You should size your database based on your expected workload.
Detailed requirements and use cases for integrated databases provides more in-
depth information on planning for an integrated database. 
 
 
 IBM Db2 Advanced Enterprise Server Edition 
Relational database that delivers advanced data management and analytics
capabilities for transactional workloads.  
Nodes:
1 node for standard deployments
3 nodes for HADR deployments
Supported storage:
hostPath storage (not supported on HADR deployments)
NFS storage
CPU and memory:Varies based on your expected workload 
For more information, see IBM Db2 Advanced Enterprise Server Edition in Detailed
requirements and use cases for integrated databases.  
 IBM Db2 Event Store 
A data store capable of high speed ingest and deep, real-time analytics. 
Nodes: 3
Supported storage:
IBM Cloud Object Storage
GlusterFS storage
Local storage (per node): 100 GB SSD with XFS format
CPU and memory:Varies based on your expected workload 
For more information, see IBM Db2 Event Store in Detailed requirements and use
cases for integrated databases.  
 IBM Db2 Warehouse 
A high-performing analytic engine that combines in-memory processing with
integrated database analytics. Runs on either a single node, for cost-efficiency, or
on multiple nodes for better performance. 
Nodes: 1, or 2-999
Supported storage:
hostPath storage

For more information, see PostgreSQL in Detailed requirements and use cases for

 Creating a database 
To create an integrated database, you must complete the following tasks:
Downloading the database installation package.
Preparing your IBM Cloud Private cluster for a database.
Configuring database storage.
Creating a database deployment on the cluster.
 
Detailed requirements and use cases for integrated databases 
 If you plan to create an integrated database in your IBM Cloud Pak for Data
cluster, ensure that you have sufficient resources for your planned workload. 
Downloading the database installation package 
 The software for installing a database in your IBM Cloud Pak for Data cluster is
provided as a separate package, which you must download to your cluster.
Preparing your IBM Cloud Private cluster for a database 
 If you plan to create a database in IBM Cloud Pak for Data, you must prepare your
cluster so that you can successfully provision the database.
Preparing your OpenShift cluster for the database 
 If you plan to create a database in IBM Cloud Pak for Data on Red Hat OpenShift,
you must prepare your cluster so that you can successfully provision the database.
Enabling GPFS support for Db2 Warehouse databases 
 As an optional storage file system, you can set up an IBM Spectrum速 Scale
storage cluster to act as a persistent volume for stateful Db2速 Warehouse
databases.
237
-
-
-
-
-
Configuring database storage 
 You must use the appropriate type of storage for your integrated database. You
can configure the storage before you create the database deployment, or when
you create the database deployment.
Creating a database deployment on the cluster 
 You create a database deployment on your cluster from the IBM Cloud Pak for
Data web client.
Updating the Db2 password secrets 
 The Db2 administration accounts on your IBM Cloud Pak for Data cluster are
protected by password secrets. During deployment of Db2 Warehouse, these
password secrets are automatically generated and securely stored for these
accounts. These accounts are used by Db2 Warehouse to handle administrative
tasks on the database. If you need to change them to comply with specific
password regulations, or if your security situation changes, you can use this
method to update the password secrets at any point in time.
Giving users access to the database 
 Whether you need to give users access to the database depends on the type of
database that you deployed.
Configuring SSL client connections with Db2 
 Use secure sockets layer (SSL) to create secure connections from Db2 clients to
the integrated  Db2 Warehouse database server deployed on IBM Cloud Pak for
Data.

 Preparing your OpenShift cluster for the database 
If you plan to create a database in IBM速 Cloud Pak for Data on Red Hat OpenShift,
you must prepare your cluster so that you can successfully provision the database. 
 Before you begin 
 
These instructions are intended to prepare a Red Hat OpenShift cluster. If you are
not preparing an OpenShift cluster, refer to Preparing your IBM Cloud Private cluster
for a database. 
Ensure that you completed the steps in Downloading the database installation
package. 
Important: This task assumes that you already have nodes in your cluster that meet
the minimum specifications for the database. If you need to add more nodes to your
cluster to meet the number of required nodes, contact your OpenShift cluster
administrator to add the necessary nodes.Use the information in Detailed
requirements and use cases for integrated databases to determine the minimum
specifications, based on the type of database you are deploying.  
 
As a prerequisite, Cloud Pak for Data checks that you meet all system requirements.
 
If Cloud Pak for Data is not installed in the default /ibm/ installation directory, you
must specify the --install-directory
INSTALL-DIRECTORY parameter and replace INSTALL-DIRECTORY with the path
of the Cloud Pak for Data installation directory. 
Db2速 Warehouse requires Security Enhanced Linux (SELinux) to be set to
permissive or disabled mode on the nodes that run Db2 Warehouse. However, this
requirement differs from the Red Hat OpenShift 3.11 prerequisites, which require
SELinux to be set to enforcing. This requirement might also conflict with your
organization's security policies for Linux hosts. To set SELinux, follow these steps: 
Open the SELinux configuration file to edit:$ vi /etc/selinux/config 
Change the line SELINUX=enforcing to SELINUX=permissive or
SELINUX=disabled.
Save the changes and close the file. Reboot the node to allow the SELinux
changes to take effect:$ reboot 
When the node starts up again, confirm that SELinux is in permissive or disabled
mode:$ getenforce
Permissive 
 About this task 
 
Cloud Pak for Data includes scripts that you can run to prepare your cluster. Use the
script to complete the following tasks:
Label nodes that can be used for a database
Enable the database package
Configure an NFS server for storing your data
 Procedure 
 
To prepare your cluster: 
SSH into the master node (master-1) on your Cloud Pak for Data cluster:ssh
account@MASTER-1-IP

Replace account with the user account that has permission to run oc commands. 
Label the database nodes in your cluster:You must label the dedicated nodes in
your cluster to be used by the database.oc label node NODE-NAME icp4data=database-dbtype 
Replace the NODE-NAME with the name of the node that is to be labeled.
Replace dbtype with the kind of database that you are using on the node:
db2wh - for Db2 Warehouse
db2oltp - for Db2 Advanced Enterprise Server Edition
db2eventstore - for IBM Db2 Event Store
mongodb - for MongoDB
postgresql - for PostgreSQL
 
 
Enable the database installation package on Cloud Pak for Data.oc exec -it $(oc get
pods -n=project | grep zen-database-core | awk {'print $1'}) \
-n project -- /tools/configure-database.sh --master MASTER-1-IP \
--ppa-archive ARCHIVE_FILE_NAME --icp-user $(oc whoami) --icp-password $(oc whoami -t) \
--registry docker-registry.default.svc:5000  --tls-verify false  --tiller-namespace tiller \
--helm-bin-path "/root/linux-amd64" --disable-tls --namespace project --enable 
Replace project with the OpenShift namespace where Cloud Pak for Data is
deployed. 
Replace MASTER-1-IP with the IP address of the master-1 node.
Replace ARCHIVE-FILE-NAME with the fully qualified path of the package that
you downloaded from IBM Passport Advantage. For example:
/ibm/InstallPackage/databases/db2wh-icp4d_x86_64_2019-07-17_12-40.tar.gz
If Cloud Pak for Data is not installed in the default /ibm/ directory, specify the --
install-directory
INSTALL-DIRECTORY parameter and replace INSTALL-DIRECTORY with the
Cloud Pak for Data installation directory.
 
If you plan to use NFS storage for your database, you can set up a server as an
NFS server by running the following command:kubectl exec -it $(kubectl get pods -n
project | grep zen-database-core | awk {'print $1'}) \
-n project -- /tools/configure-database.sh --password SSH-PASSWORD \
--nfs-server NFS-SERVER-IP --storage-dir STORAGE-DIRECTORY --setup-nfs 
Important: This command creates an NFS server that is not highly available. If
you need highly available NFS storage, you must follow your own procedures to
configure the storage.  
Replace the following values:
Replace project with the OpenShift namespace where Cloud Pak for Data is
deployed. 
Replace SSH-PASSWORD with the SSH password for the NFS server. If your
password contains a special character, such as an exclamation mark (!),
surround the password with single quotation marks ('). 
Replace NFS-SERVER-IP with the IP address of the server where you want to

As an optional storage file system, you can set up an IBM Spectrum速 Scale storage
cluster to act as a persistent volume for stateful Db2速 Warehouse databases. 
 Before you begin 
 
You need a IBM Spectrum Scale cluster that is configured to work as a cloud
storage repository. IBM Spectrum Scale is the new name for IBM速 General Parallel
File System. The details of setting up an IBM Spectrum Scale storage system are
beyond the scope of this document. For more information about the capabilities of
IBM Spectrum Scale and the installation requirements and process, see the official
documentation.You need to configure the worker nodes of your IBM Cloud Pak for
Data cluster to serve as client nodes of the IBM Spectrum Scale cluster. 
Determine which product edition of the IBM Spectrum Scale Cluster software is
right for your environment, based on your hardware and specific performance
characteristics. There is a comprehensive listing of the available editions in the
IBM Spectrum Scale documentation.
Download the IBM Spectrum Scale Cluster software from IBM Fix Central onto
the master node. Choose the version of the client software to match what is
installed on the IBM Spectrum Scale cluster. The platform must correspond to the
architecture and operating system of your Cloud Pak for Data worker nodes.
You need to install the toolkit on all the worker nodes that use the IBM Spectrum
Scale storage. The toolkit installation instructions are available in the IBM
Spectrum Scale documentation.
For a detailed set of instructions on installing IBM Spectrum Scale cluster, see
the Protocols Quick Overview for IBM Spectrum Scale (PDF). If you already
have your IBM Spectrum Scale cluster, and need to configure only the client
nodes, review the sections of that document titled Before You Begin and Protocol
& File System Deployment.
 
You need to have root access on the master nodes on the Cloud Pak for Data
cluster and to the nodes the IBM Spectrum Scale cluster. 
 About this task 
 
This task covers installation of the IBM Storage Enabler for Containers plug-in on
your Cloud Pak for Data cluster, configuration of the storage class, and setting IBM
Spectrum Scale as a persistent volume when you provision your Db2 Warehouse
database.Note: If you do not want to use the dynamically provisioned storage class
that is provided by the IBM Storage Enabler for Containers plug-in, use the hostPath
option when you provision your database. Set the hostPath to point to a directory on
the mount point for your IBM Spectrum Scale storage cluster, and skip the
remainder of this task.

You create a database deployment on your cluster from the IBM速 Cloud Pak for

 Before you begin 
 
Ensure that you completed the steps in Preparing your IBM Cloud Private cluster for

 About this task 
 
You must have the Provision add-ons permission to complete this task. 
Tip: If you are deploying a sandbox environment, you can use the Create with
defaults option to deploy the database. However, you don't have any control over

 Procedure 
 
From the navigation, select Collect > My data.
Open the Databases tab.Restriction: This tab is displayed only if you completed
the previous steps under Creating an integrated database. 
 
Click Create a database.
Select the database type and version. Click Next.
(IBM Db2速 Warehouse only) Specify the number of nodes to use.You are
constrained by the total number of nodes in the cluster.  
 
Specify the number of cores to use.You are constrained by the total number of
cores on the node. For example, if you created a node with 16 cores, you can
specify up to 16 cores. If the database is deployed on multiple nodes, the
resources must exist on each node.  
 
Specify the amount of memory to use.You are constrained by the total amount of
memory on the node. For example, if you created a node with 512 GB of
memory, you can specify up to 512 GB. If the database is deployed on multiple
nodes, the resources must exist on each node.  
 
Specify whether you want to deploy the database on dedicated nodes.It is
recommended that you deploy the database on dedicated nodes for production
workloads to ensure that the database has sufficient resources. However, this
option is available only if you used the --add-database-node option when you
prepared your cluster. 
(PostgreSQL only) The database can be deployed on dedicated nodes only.  
If you cannot select this option or if you choose not to deploy the database on
dedicated nodes, the nodes might be used by other add-ons or services. 
 
(IBM Db2 Advanced Enterprise Server Edition only) Specify whether you want to
Enable high availability disaster recovery (HADR).Important: HADR deployments
require extra nodes for failover support. You must have nodes available with
enough resources in your cluster before you deploy the database:

 Updating the Db2 password secrets 
The Db2 administration accounts on your IBM速 Cloud Pak for Data cluster are
protected by password secrets. During deployment of Db2 Warehouse, these
password secrets are automatically generated and securely stored for these
accounts. These accounts are used by Db2 Warehouse to handle administrative
tasks on the database. If you need to change them to comply with specific password
regulations, or if your security situation changes, you can use this method to update
the password secrets at any point in time. 
 About this task 
 
These commands update the passwords for both the Db2 instance user account,
and the Db2 admin account, which is kept in the local Db2 LDAP service. This
change must be run on the master node, and requires the kubectl command. You
need a user account with sufficient authority to run the kubectl patch and kubectl
delete commands in the namespace where your Db2 Warehouse instance is
running. Procedure 
 
SSH into the master node (master-1) on your Cloud Pak for Data cluster.ssh account
@MASTER-1-IP 
Replace account with the user account that has permission to run kubectl
commands. 
Run the following kubectl command from the command line to get the database
instance identifier.kubectl get pods -n NAMESPACE | grep db2wh 
Replace NAMESPACE with the namespace where your database instance is
running on the cluster. The command returns a string that contains the instance
identifier number:  
db2wh-1546024110-db2u-0 
In this example, the instance identifier of the database is 1546024110. 
Run the following kubectl commands from your command line to update the
password in the secret object.kubectl patch -n NAMESPACE $(kubectl get secret -n NAMESPACE -o
name | grep "INSTANCE_ID-db2u-instance") \
-p $"{\"data\":{\"password\": \"$(echo INSTANCE_NEW_PASSWORD | base64)\"}}" 
kubectl patch -n NAMESPACE $(kubectl get secret -n NAMESPACE -o name | grep "INSTANCE_ID-db2u-ldap-
bluadmin") \
-p $"{\"data\":{\"password\": \"$(echo LDAP_BLUEADMIN_PASSWORD | base64)\"}}" 
 Replace NAMESPACE with the namespace where your Db2 instance is running
and INSTANCE_ID with the numerical identifier that was returned from the
previous step. Replace INSTANCE_NEW_PASSWORD with the new password
for the Db2 instance and LDAP_BLUEADMIN_PASSWORD with the new admin
password.  
Restart the affected cluster pods. In the following commands, replace
NAMESPACE with the namespace where your Db2 instance is running and
INSTANCE_ID with the numerical identifier that was returned from the earlier
command. 
 Restart the Db2 LDAP pod:kubectl delete -n NAMESPACE $(kubectl get po -n NAMESPACE -o name |
grep "INSTANCE_ID-db2u-ldap") 
 
Restart the Db2 database pods:kubectl delete -n NAMESPACE $(kubectl get po -n NAMESPACE -o
274
name | grep -E "INSTANCE_ID-db2u-[0-9]")
 
 
Restart the Db2 tools pod:kubectl delete -n NAMESPACE $(kubectl get po -n NAMESPACE -o name |
grep "INSTANCE_ID-db2u-tools") 
 
Restart the unified console:kubectl delete -n NAMESPACE $(kubectl get po -n NAMESPACE -o name |
grep "INSTANCE_ID-ibm-unified-console")

If you are deploying IBM Db2 Event Store, you might have to wait several minutes for the database to be deployed. If you are deploying IBM Db2 Warehouse, you might have to wait 2 - 40 minutes, based on the number of worker nodes and amount of memory allocated to the deployment.

 Installing the Watson Speech to Text add-on 
You can install the Watson Speech to Text add-on on top of IBM速 Cloud Pak for
Data. 
 Introduction 
This document contains installation instructions for both Watson Speech to Text and
Watson Text to Speech solutions. 
Watson Speech to Text (STT) provides speech recognition capabilities for your
solutions. The service uses machine learning to combine knowledge of grammar,
language structure, and the composition of audio and voice signals to accurately
transcribe the human voice. It continuously updates and refines its transcription as it
receives more speech. 
Watson Text to Speech (TTS) service converts written text to natural-sounding
speech to provide speech-synthesis capabilities for applications. It gives you the
freedom to customize your own preferred speech in different languages. This cURL-
based tutorial can help you get started quickly with the service. 
 Chart details 
This chart can be used to install a single instance of both the STT and TTS
solutions. The solutions can be installed separately; however, if both are installed
together they share their datastores for a more efficient utilization of resources and
simplified support. 
 Prerequisites 
Cloud Pak for Data 2.1.0
Kubernetes 1.12.4 or later
Helm 2.9.1 or later 
 
Because the installation of the chart needs to be performed from the command line,
you must install and configure Helm and kubectl. 
 Select the components to install 
This chart can be used to install both the STT and TTS solutions, the following tags,
which are defined in the values.yaml file, can be used to enable the installation of
each of the different components shipped in this solution.tags:
 sttAsync: true
 sttCustomization: true
 ttsCustomization: true
 sttRuntime: true
 ttsRuntime: true 
 
sttAsync
enables the installation of the asynchronous API to access the STT service,
which corresponds to the /recognitions API endpoints. 
sttCustomization
enables the installation of the STT customization functionality, which lets you
customize the STT base models for improved accuracy and corresponds to the
/customizations API endpoints. 
ttsCustomization
enables the installation of the TTS customization functionality, which lets you
customize the TTS base voices for improved voice quality and corresponds to
the /customizations API endpoints. 
116
-
-
-
-
sttRuntime
enables the installation of the core STT functionality, which lets you convert
speech into text using the /recognize endpoint. Note that this component is
installed if either the sttRuntime, sttCustomization, or sttAsync tags
are set to true. 
ttsRuntime
enables the installation of the core TTS functionality, which lets you convert text
into speech using the /synthesize endpoint. Note that this component is
installed if either the ttsRuntime or ttsCustomization tags are set to
true. 
By default all the components are enabled, but each of them can be disabled
separately. If you want to install STT only, you need to set ttsRuntime and
ttsCustomization to false. Similarly, if you want to install TTS only, you need
to set sttRuntime, sttCustomization and sttAsync to false. For example,
if you want to install STT and TTS but do not want customization capabilities, then
you need to set sttCustomization and ttsCustomization to false. 
 Namespace 
The first step consists of creating the Kubernetes namespace where the solution is
installed. The example that follows shows how to create the namespace, which in
this case is named speech-services. You can use a different name for the
namespace. 
Copy the following YAML to a file, then run the command that follows the YAML.
apiVersion: v1
kind: Namespace
metadata:
 name: speech-services 
kubectl create -f {namespace_file} 
 
 MinIO object storage 
MinIO object storage is used for storing persistence data needed by speech service
components. 
PersistenceIn order to use MinIO you need to have running GlusterFS server and
create storage class oketi-gluster. Information about installing GlusterFS under
IBM Cloud Private can be found here. It is possible you have created oketi-
gluster storage class during IBM Cloud Private installation however if not here is
how to do it afterwards:cat > oketi-gluster.yaml << EOF
 apiVersion: storage.k8s.io/v1
 kind: StorageClass
 metadata:
   name: oketi-gluster
 parameters:
   nodes: |
     [
       { "Hostname":"HOST", "IP":"$GLUSTER_SERVER", "Path":"$GLUSTER_DIR"},
     ]
   volumeType: glusterfs
 provisioner: oketi
 reclaimPolicy: Retain
117
 volumeBindingMode: Immediate
EOF 
 
$GLUSTER_SERVER should be the address of the GlusterFS server and $NFS_DIR
should be the root of the glusterfs directory. After modifying and saving the file
as appropriately, run the command: kubectl apply -f
       oketi-nfs.yaml 
 
It's worth pointing out that the GlusterFS server has to be installed with sufficient
space size. Size calculation is described in the section Storage size calculation
guidelines. 
 
SecretsBefore you install STT or TTS, you need to provide a secret object that is
used by MinIO itself and by other service components that interact with MinIO. This
secret contains the security keys to access MinIO. 
The secret must contain the items accesskey (5 - 20 characters) and secretkey
(8 - 40 characters) in base64 encoding. Therefore, before creating the secret, you
need to perform the base64 enconding. 
The following commands encode the accesskey and secretkey in base64.
Important: For security reasons, you are strongly encouraged to create an
accesskey and a secretkey that are different from the sample keys (admin and
admin1234) that are shown in the examples.echo -n "admin" | base64
YWRtaW4=
 
echo -n "admin1234" | base64
YWRtaW4xMjM0 
 
Create file minio.yaml with the following secret object definition:apiVersion: v1
kind: Secret
metadata:
 name: minio
type: Opaque
data:
 accesskey: YWRtaW4=
 secretkey: YWRtaW4xMjM0 
kubectl create -f minio.yaml 
 
 
Mode of operationBy default, MinIO is operating in distributed mode which
means that MinIO is scheduled to run multiple instance on every worked node to
assure storage high availability. 
In order to optimally use HA, you have to specify number of replicas. Set the number
of replicas for distributed mode e.g external.minio.repliacas=N where N is
number of the number of cluster nodes; it must be 4 <= x <= 32 (default value is
4 replicas). 
MinIO also operates in standalone mode which means that only one instance of
MinIO is running on arbitrary worker node and its failure means that service will not
be available until new instance is running and healthy. This options is sufficient for
118
-
-
-
-
-
testing purposes but not production. 
If you want to run MinIO in standalone mode, you can do it with setting value
external.minio.mode=standalone in which case you don't have to set
external.minio.replicas. 
 
Storage size calculation guidelinesObject storage is used for storing binary data
from the following sources:
Base models (for example en_US-NarrowbandModel) 
On average, base models are each 1.5 GB. Because models are updated
regularly, you need to multiply that amount by three to make room for at least three
different versions of each model. 
Customization data (audio files and training snapshots) 
The storage required for customization data depends on how many hours of audio
you use for training your custom models. On average, one hour of audio data
needs 0.5 GB of storage space. You can have multiple customizations, so you
must factor in additional space. 
Audio files from recognition jobs that are processed asynchronously, in case they
need to be queued 
The storage required for asynchronous jobs depends on the use case. If you plan
to submit large batches of audio files, expect the service to queue some jobs
temporarily. This means that some audio files are held temporarily in binary
storage. The amount of storage required for this purpose does not exceed the size
of the largest batch of jobs that you plan to submit in parallel. 
 
A few examples of how to calculate storage size [GB] follow:
6 models, 3 versions, 50 hours audio = 6 * 1.5 * 3 + 50 * 0.5 = 52
2 models, 3 versions, 20 hours audio = 2 * 1.5 * 3 + 20 * 0.5 = 19
 
The default storage size, 100 GB, is a minimal starting point and is typically enough
for operations with two to six models and about 50 hours of audio for the purpose of
training custom models. That said, it is always a good idea to be generous in
anticipation of future storage needs. 
 
 Configuration of the PostgreSQL and RabbitMQ installation 
 
Create Local Persistent Volumes to persist dataIf either STT customization, TTS
customization or STT async are included in the installation (see the previous
section: Select the Components to Install) an instance of the PostgreSQL database
is installed. Additionally, if the STT async component is included in the installation,
an instance of the RabbitMQ datastore is installed. The datastores are stateful and
need to leverage Kubernetes persistent volumes to persist their data. 
PostgreSQL and RabbitMQ require the availability of Kubernetes Local Persistent
Volumes, which must be created before you install the chart. The volumes are used
to persist the data used by the datastores so if a container restarts it can reattach to
the original data. Given that both PostgreSQL and RabbitMQ are configured by
default for high availability (HA) with three replicas, a minimum of three volumes
need to be installed for each of the datastores.apiVersion: v1
kind: PersistentVolume
119
-
-
-
-
-
-
-
-
metadata:
 name: {name}
spec:
 capacity:
   storage: {size}Gi
 accessModes:
 - ReadWriteOnce
 persistentVolumeReclaimPolicy: Retain
 storageClassName: local-storage-local
 local:
   path: {path}
 nodeAffinity:
   required:
     nodeSelectorTerms:
     - matchExpressions:
       - key: kubernetes.io/hostname
         operator: In
         values:
         - {node} 
 
where:
{name}
is the name of the Persistent Volume (PV) to be created, and needs to be
unique.
{size}
s the disk space that is allocated for the persistent volume.
{path}
is the path in the host machine where the persistent volume is created; for
example, /mnt/local-storage/storage/pv_1. Note that the permissions
of this directory need to be open enough to allow non-root access; otherwise,
pods running as non-root are unable to mount the volume in the directory.
{node}
is the Kubernetesworker node where the Local Volume is to be created. You
can list the available nodes in your cluster by running kubectl get nodes.
 
Given that PostgreSQL and RabbitMQ pods are scheduled in the worker nodes
where the PVs are created, the PVs need to be created in different nodes so in case
a node goes down there are still at least two healthy replicas running. Recall that a
minimum of three replicas are needed for high availability. 
 
Setting access credentials for PostgreSQLThe PostgreSQL chart reads the
credentials to access the PostgreSQL database from the following secret file, which
needs to be created before installing the chart. You need to set the attribute
data.pg_su_password to the PostgreSQL password that you want (base64
encoded). You also need to set the attribute pg_repl_password, which is the
replication password and is also base64 encoded, to the value you want.apiVersion: v1
data:
 pg_repl_password: cmVwbHVzZXI=
120
-
-
-
-
-
 pg_su_password: c3RvbG9u
kind: Secret
metadata:
 name: user-provided-postgressql # this name can be anything you choose
type: Opaque 
 
To create this secret object you need to execute the command kubectl create -f
       {secrets_file} 
 
Finally, when installing the chart you need to set the following two values to the
name of the secret created previously (user-provided-postgressql):
global.datastores.postgressql.auth.authSecretName and
postgressql.auth.authSecretName. 
If you do not create the secret object, the system creates a secret object that
contains randomly generated passwords when the Helm chart is installed. For
security reasons you need to change the automatically generated passwords when
the deployment is complete. 
 
 Resources required 
In addition to the general requirements listed in Pre-installation tasks, the Watson
Speech to Text service has its own requirements:
x86 is the only architecture supported at this time.
If you need a highly available installation a minimum of three worker nodes are
needed for the installation.
The resources required for the installation, in terms of CPUs and memory, depend
on the configuration that you select. There are two typical installation
configurations: 
The development configuration, which is the configuration that is used in the
default installation, has a minimal footprint and is meant for development
purposes and as a proof of concept. It can handle several concurrent recognition
sessions only and it is not highly available since some of the core component
have no redundancy (single replica).
The production configuration is a highly available solution that is intended to
run production workloads. This configuration can be achieved by scaling up the
development configuration after installation, see the next section.
 
Resources required by the standard Watson Speech to Text installationWhile
the default installation of the solution comes with the development configuration,
you can easily obtain the production configuration by scaling up the number of
pods/replicas of the deployment objects after installing the solution. How much to
scale up each of the components depends on the degree of concurrency you need,
and is limited by the amount of hardware resources available in your Kubernetes
cluster/namespace. 
Scaling up the PostgreSQL and RabbitMQ datastores 
By default both PostgreSQL and RabbitMQ are installed with three replicas for high
availability reasons. Each replica is typically scheduled within a different Kubernetes
worker node if resources allow. Before performing the installation, you can configure
the number of replicas and the CPU and memory resources for each replica by
121
1.
2.
3.
using Helm values (see the Options section). 
You can also scale up the datastores on an already running solution by changing
the number of replicas in the Deployment or StatefulSet objects. For example, you
can scale up RabbitMQ as follows:
 Edit the StatefulSet object by running kubectl edit statefulsets
{release}-ibm-rabbitmq.
Change the value of the spec.replicas: attribute.
Save and close the StatefulSet object. 
 
In the case of PostgreSQL there are two deployment objects ({release}-ibm-
postgresql-proxy and {release}-ibm-postgresql-sentinel) and a
StatefulSet (ibm-wc-ibm-postgresql-keeper). The deployment objects can be
scaled up by simply running kubectl scale --replicas={n}
{deployment_object} where {n} is the new number of replicas; for example,
kubectl scale--replicas=3 deployment
ibm-wc-ibm-postgresql-proxy. The StatefulSet object can be scaled up
following the process described previously for PostgreSQL. 
Note that a sufficient number of Persistent Local Volumes need to be created before
scaling up the number of replicas (in the case of the StatefulSets) so the newly
created pods can mount their volumes. 
Scaling up the rest of the solution 
You can learn about the list of deployments (KubernetesDeployment objects) by
running the kubectl get deployment command. You can then scale up the
number of pods on each of the deployment objects to match the number of pods in
the production configuration, as shown in the following table. You can do this by
using the following command: kubectl scale --replicas={n} deployment
{deployment_object}, where {n} is the desired number of replicas for the given
deployment ({deployment_object}). Table 1. Deployments
Deployment Default number of replicas
{release}-speech-to-text-stt-
runtime
1
{release}-speech-to-text-stt-
customization
1
{release}-speech-to-text-stt-am-
patcher
1
{release}-speech-to-text-stt-
async
1
{release}-speech-to-text-gdpr-
data-deletion
1
{release}-minio 1
{release}-rabbitmq 1
{release}-ibm-postgressql-proxy 2
{release}-ibm-postgressql-
sentinel
3
{release}-ibm-postgressql-
keeper
3
122
-
-
-
 
Table 2. Statefulsets
 
 
The standard installation (development configuration) requires a total of 14.75 CPUs
and 38.5 GBs of memory. These numbers are based on a standard installation that
includes the US English models only. In general, the memory requirements vary
depending on which models you include in the installation. 
Setting the sessions/CPU ratio 
Session in this context is one of these:
recognize request to the STT runtime
synthesize request to the TTS runtime
train request to the STT Customization back-end (STT AM Patcher)train
request to the STT Customization back-end (STT AM Patcher)
 
In order to choose resources for each of the session types, you have to do the
following calculations. 
 
 
Dynamic resource calculationSTT Runtime, TTS Runtime and STT Customization
Back-End supports automatic required memory resource calculation, which is based
on the selected number of CPUs and the selected language models. Automatic
resource calculation is enabled by default. You can modify this behavior by setting
following values to true/false:sttRuntime.groups.sttRuntimeDefault.resources.dynamicMemory
ttsRuntime.groups.ttsRuntimeDefault.resources.dynamicMemory
sttAMPatcher.groups.sttAMPatcher.resources.dynamicMemory 
 
When you set any of the previous values to false you have to specify required
memory yourself (see Options section below). 
Disclaimer: Disabling automatic resource calculation is not recommended and can
cause undesired service behavior. 
 
 PodSecurityPolicy Requirements 
The predefined PodSecurityPolicy name: ibm-anyuid-psp has been verified for
this chart. By default the chart automatically installs the necessary RBAC roles and
rolebindings for running the service. 
Custom PodSecurityPolicy definition:--- 
 
 Pre-install steps 
Run: ./ibm_cloud_pak/pak_extensions/pre-install/clusterAdministration/labelNamespace.sh
       ICP4D_NAMESPACE 
 where ICP4D_NAMESPACE is the namespace where Cloud Pak for Data is installed
(usually zen). 
Statefulset Number of replicas
ibm-wc-ibm-postgresql-keeper 3
ibm-wc-ibm-rabbitmq 3
123
-
-
-
The ICP4D_NAMESPACE namespace must have a label for the NetworkPolicy to
correctly work. Only nginx and zen pods are allowed to communicate with the
pods in the namespace where this chart is installed. 
 Installing the chart on IBM Cloud Pak for Data (without Red
Hat OpenShift) 
Installing the Helm chart deploys a single IBM Watson Speech Services solution
with the development configuration. You can then scale up this configuration to
support up to 50 concurrent recognition sessions (see the earlier sections). 
To install the chart, run the following command:helm install --tls --name {my_release} -f
{my_values.yaml} ibm-watson-speech-prod 
Replace {my_release} with a name for your release.
Replace {my_values.yaml} with the path to a YAML file that specifies the
values that are to be used with the install command. Specifying a YAML file is
optional.
 
When the command completes, its output shows the current status of the release. 
When the installation has completed and all the pods are in ready state, a series of
Helm tests are available to validate the installation. They can be executed by using
the following command:helm test --tls --name {my_release} 
 
Important:Security Notice - After completing the installation, it is strongly
recommended that you manually change any autogenerated passwords or
certificate. If not, the Helm CLI can allow a user with operator role to see the
password or certificate, which represents a security risk. 
PodSecurityPolicy requirementsThis chart requires a PodSecurityPolicy to be
bound to the target namespace prior to installation. This chart has been verified with
the predefined ibm-restricted-psp' PodSecurityPolicy. Choose either a
predefined PodSecurityPolicy or have your cluster administrator create a custom
PodSecurityPolicy for you: 
Custom PodSecurityPolicy definition:--- 
 
 
Uninstalling the chartTo uninstall and delete the my_release deployment, run the
following command:helm delete --tls my_release 
 
To irrevocably uninstall and delete the my_release deployment, run the following
command:helm delete --purge --tls my_release 
 
If you omit the --purge option, Helm deletes all resources for the deployment but
retains the record with the release name. This allows you to roll back the deletion. If
you include the --purge option, Helm removes all records for the deployment so
that the name can be used for another installation. 
 
 Installing the chart on IBM Cloud Pak for Data with Red Hat
OpenShift 
This Helm chart deploys a single IBM Watson Speech Services instance. 
OpenShift software prerequisites
IBM Cloud Pak for Data V2.1.0.1
124
-
-

Kubernetes V1.11.0
Helm V2.9.0
 Before installing the Speech Services solution, you must install and configure helm
and kubectl. 
 
Red Hat OpenShift SecurityContextConstraints RequirementsThis chart
requires a SecurityContextConstraints to be bound to the target namespace prior to
installation. To meet this requirement there might be cluster-scoped as well as
namespace-scoped pre and post actions that need to occur. 
The predefined SecurityContextConstraints name restricted has been verified
for this chart. If your target namespace is bound to this SecurityContextConstraints
resource you can proceed to install the chart. 
If necessary, run the following command to bind the restricted
SecurityContextConstraints to your namespace:oc adm policy add-scc-to-group restricted
system:serviceaccounts:{namespace-name} 
 
This chart also defines a custom SecurityContextConstraints that can be used to
finely control the permissions and capabilities needed to deploy this chart. You can
enable this custom SecurityContextConstraints resource using the supplied
instructions and scripts in the pak_extension pre-install directory.
From the user interface, you can copy and paste the following snippets to enable
the custom SecurityContextConstraints:

priority: null
readOnlyRootFilesystem: false
requiredDropCapabilities:
- KILL
- MKNOD
- SETUID
- SETGID
runAsUser:

seLinuxContext:
 type: MustRunAs
supplementalGroups:
 type: RunAsAny
users: []
volumes:
- configMap
- downwardAPI
- emptyDir
- persistentVolumeClaim

From the command line, you can run the setup scripts included under
pak_extensions. 
For cluster admin, the pre-install instructions are located at: 
pre-install/clusterAdministration/Notes.md 
 For team admin the namespace scoped instructions are located at:
pre-install/namespaceAdministration/Notes.md 
 
 
 
Installing the chartThe cluster-admin role is required to deploy IBM Watson
Speech Services.
Log into OpenShift and Dockeroc login
docker login -u $(oc whoami) -p $(oc whoami -t) {docker-registry} 
{docker-registry} is the address of the OpenShiftDocker registry; for
example, docker-registry-default.apps.speech-
openshift.ibm.com. You can find the URL of the Docker registry in the
OpenShift console.
From the OpenShift command line tool, create the namespace in which to
deploy the service; for example, speech-services. Use the following
command to create the namespace:oc new-project {namespace-name}

name} 
{namespace-name} is the Kubernetes and Docker namespace that you
created in Step 1.
Extract the PPA archive contents:cd {compressed-file-dir}
tar -xvfz {compressed-file-name}

{compressed-file-dir} is the directory where you downloaded

registry}

If you cannot access the Kubernetes command line tool, see Enabling access to

Create persistent volumes for the service.

where {namespace-name} is the namespace where IBM Cloud Pak for Data is
installed (normally zen). 
Create secrets.Two secret objects need to be created manually within the
{namespace-name} namespace to set the access credentials for the MinIO
and PostgreSQL datastores. In order to set credentials for MinIO see the

At a minimum, you must provide your own values for the following configurable

namespace. For example, docker-

 See the section Select the components to install for information on how to
select the components to install. Additionally, read the Installation appendix and
Configuration section to learn more about the installation configuration.
After you define any custom configuration settings, you can install the chart from
the Helm command line interface. Enter the following command from the
directory where the package was loaded in your local system:helm install --namespace
{namespace-name} --name {release-name} {compressed-file-dir}/charts/ibm-watson-speech-prod/ --tiller-
namespace {tiller-namespace} 
{tiller-namespace} is the namespace where Tiller is installed within the
cluster (typically the zen namespace).
{release-name} is the name of the Helm release.
 
 
 Configuration 
The Helm chart has the following values that you can override by using the --set
parameter with the install command. For example:helm install --tls --set
image.repository={my_image} stable/ibm-datapower-dev 
 
Alternatively, you can provide a YAML file that specifies the values with the
127
install command. For example:helm install --tls -f {my_values.yaml} 
 
Language model selectionYou can perform an installation that includes only a
subset of the language models/voices in the catalog. Installing all of the
models/voices in the catalog substantially increases the memory requirements.
Therefore, it is strongly recommended that you install only those languages that you
will use. 
You can select the languages to be installed by checking or unchecking each of the
models/voices in global.sttModels.* or global.ttsVoices.* values. By
default, the dynamic resource calculation feature is enabled; it automatically
computes the exact amount of memory that is required for the selected
models/voices. 
It is also possible to install ad hoc models/voices that was not released with this
version. You need to download special package containing data for the
models/voices, upload it into the cluster the same way as main package and specify
following options during installation. 
Table 3. Language model selection
 
As an example, assume that there is a new broadband model for Czech language
that was released as an ad hoc model for current Speech on IBM Cloud Private
release. In order to enable it during update, specify following options during
installation. For this example, $modelName is csCSBroadbandModel and
$catalogName is cs-CS_BroadBandModel:helm upgrade RELEASE CHART --set
global.sttModels.csCSBroadbandModel.catalogName=cs-CS_BroadBandModel --set
global.sttModels.csCSBroadbandModel.size=500 [OTHER-FLAGS]
 
 
 
Storage of customer data (STT Runtime and AMC Patcher)By default, payload
data, including audio files, recognition hypotheses, and annotations, are temporarily
stored in the running container. You can disable this behavior by checking STT
Runtime | Disable storage

There are two typical installation configurations: The development configuration, which is the configuration that is used in the default installation, has a minimal footprint and is meant for development purposes and as a proof of concept. It can handle several concurrent recognition sessions only and it is not highly available since some of the core component have no redundancy (single replica).
